verses.text: After some time, during the wheat harvest, Samson went to visit his wife, bringing a young goat. He said, “I will go in to my wife in her room.” But her father would not let him go in.
verses.comment: The phrase 'go in to my wife' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew, indicating marital relations.

verses.text: Her father said, “I really thought you hated her, so I gave her to your companion. Is not her younger sister better than she? Please take her instead.”
verses.comment: 'Companion' likely refers to the best man or close friend from the wedding context.

verses.text: Samson said to them, “This time I will be blameless regarding the Philistines, when I do them harm.”
verses.comment: 'Blameless' signifies Samson sees his actions now as justified.

verses.text: So Samson went and caught three hundred foxes, and took torches, and turned tail to tail and put a torch between each pair of tails.
verses.comment: 'Foxes' could possibly mean jackals according to some scholars, but the literal Hebrew is preserved here.

verses.text: Then he set fire to the torches and let the foxes go into the Philistines’ standing grain. He burned up the shock and the standing grain, as well as the vineyards and olive groves.
verses.comment: This verse shows deliberate destruction of food resources.

verses.text: Then the Philistines said, “Who has done this?” And they were told, “Samson, son-in-law of the Timnite, because he took his wife and gave her to his companion.” So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father with fire.
verses.comment: Tragic fulfillment of earlier threat in Judges 14:15.

verses.text: Samson said to them, “Since you did this, I swear I will not stop until I have taken revenge on you.”
verses.comment: Samson declares intent for personal vengeance.

verses.text: He struck them cruelty with a great slaughter, then went down and stayed in the cleft of the rock at Etam.
verses.comment: 'He struck them cruelty' translates the Hebrew idiom meaning 'with great force.'

verses.text: Then the Philistines went up, encamped in Judah, and spread out in Lehi.
verses.comment: Lehi means 'jawbone' in Hebrew, foreshadowing Samson's weapon.

verses.text: The people of Judah said, “Why have you come against us?” They answered, “We have come to arrest Samson and do to him as he has done to us.”
verses.comment: The cycle of retaliation between Samson and the Philistines is emphasized here.

verses.text: Then three thousand men of Judah went down to the cleft of the rock at Etam and said to Samson, “Do you not know that the Philistines rule over us? What is this you have done to us?” He said to them, “As they did to me, so I did to them.”
verses.comment: Judah's subjection to the Philistines is clearly expressed.

verses.text: They said to him, “We have come to arrest you and hand you over to the Philistines.” Samson said, “Swear to me that you will not attack me yourselves.”
verses.comment: Samson wants assurance his fellow Israelites will not kill him.

verses.text: They answered him, “No, we will only arrest you and hand you over to them; we will not kill you.” So they bound him with two new ropes and brought him up from the rock.
verses.comment: 'New ropes' are mentioned to show their strength and Samson's miraculous escape.

verses.text: As he came to Lehi, the Philistines came shouting against him. Then the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him, and the ropes on his arms became like flax that had been burned with fire, and his bonds dropped from his hands.
verses.comment: 'The Spirit of the LORD' refers to empowerment for supernatural strength.

verses.text: He found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, reached out his hand and took it, and with it struck down a thousand men.
verses.comment: The jawbone is specifically described as 'fresh,' implying it was still strong.

verses.text: Samson said, “With the jawbone of a donkey, heaps upon heaps, with the jawbone of a donkey I have struck down a thousand men.”
verses.comment: Literal translation of Samson’s poetic utterance. 'Heaps upon heaps' reflects wordplay in Hebrew.

verses.text: When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone out of his hand. That place was called Ramath-lehi.
verses.comment: Ramath-lehi means “Height of the jawbone.”

verses.text: He was very thirsty, so he called to the LORD and said, “You have granted this great salvation by the hand of your servant; now shall I die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?”
verses.comment: 'Uncircumcised' is a term denoting Philistines as outsiders to God's covenant.

verses.text: But God split open the hollow place at Lehi, and water came out. When he drank, his spirit returned and he revived. So it was called En-hakkore, which is at Lehi to this day.
verses.comment: 'En-hakkore' means 'spring of the one who called.' Shows God’s miraculous provision.

verses.text: Samson judged Israel for twenty years in the days of the Philistines.
verses.comment: 'Judged' here means 'led' or 'ruled' as a deliverer.
